div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7,632] ALEXANDRIA, MONDAY, DECEMBER 10, 1906. [EIGHT PAGES P.T. 1.
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.
Throw Steel Nibs Away!
They waste time, are costly to use, wear out, scratch, etc.
Try a "Swan" Fountain Pen.
Prices from 10/6
Sold by all Stationers and Importers in Cairo and Alexandria.
Catalogue free.
Mable, Todd & Bard, High Holborn, London.

R.M.S. “Ophir" will leave Port Said December 31

The issue of return tickets to and from Egypt has been discontinued. Passengers paying full fare one direction will, however, be allowed abatement of one-third off fare back if return voyage be made within four months of arrival, or abatement of 20 o/o if return voyage be made within six months of arrival.
Special reduced rates during Summer season 15th May - 15th September.
Agents, Cairo: Thomas Cook & Son, Ltd. ; Alexandria : R. J. Moss & Co.

div.head: Deutsche Levante-Linie.
div.p: Mail and Passenger Steamships. Regular three-weekly Service from HAMBURG, via ANTWERP & MALTA, to ALEXANDRIA and vice-versa, admitting goods from all chief German Railway Stations on direct Bill of Landing to ALEXANDRIA and all chief ports of Egypt, Syria, etc., at favourable through rates of DEUTSCHE VERKEHR (traffic).
EXPECTED AT ALEXANDRIA.
S.S. Naxos December 13 from Hamburg.
S.S. Andros July 20 from Antwerp bound for Rott. Hamburg.
Discharging. For tariff and particulars apply to ADOLPHE STROSS, Alexandria, Agent.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez weekly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for Port Sudan and Suakin direct returning fromSuakin every Wednesday noon. Every Monday at 6 p.m. a steamer leaves Suez for Jeddah continuing every other week to Suakin, Massowah, Hodeidab, Aden. Intermediate steamers do not proceed beyond Jeddah Lat call at Tor, (for Sinai) El Wedj and yambo as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: The Moss S.S. Company, Ltd.
div.p: For LIVERPOOL calling at MALTA (Messrs. JAMES MOSS & Co. 31, James St, Liverpool, Managers.)

div.head: Austrian Lloyd’s Steam Navigation
div.p: Alexandria-Brindisi-Trieste (Venice).

Weekly Express Mail Service. Steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m. arrive at Brindisi, Tuesday 5 a.m. in time for express to Milan, Lucerne, Paris, Vienna, Berlin, and London, leaving Brindisi 7 a.m. Arrival Trieste Wednesday about 11 a.m. in connection with Train de Luxe Trieste-Vienna-Ostende. Passengers reach London every Friday 4.50 p.m.
Weekly Intermediate Service: Alexandria-Brindisi & Trieste Line.
Steamer leaves Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. arrive Brindisi Sunday at 5a.m. Trieste Tuesday.
Syrian-Cyprus-Caramanian Line.
Steamer leaves Alexandria on or about 19 November, 3, 17 and 31 December.
Syrian-Caramanian Line.
Steamer leaves Alexandria on or about 26 November, 10 and 24 December.
Far East Lines.

To Suez, Aden and Bombay accelerated service about 8 December, 8 Nov.
To Suez, Aden, Karachi, Colombo, Madras, Rangoon, and Calcutta about 19 Nov, 19 Dec 4 p.m.
To Suez, Aden, Karachi and Bombay about 13 Dec.(Winter Line).
East African Line.
Departures from Port Said: To Suez, Aden, Mombassa, Zanzibar, Beira, Delagoa-Bay, and Durban about 3 Dec., 2 Nov., 3 Dec..

div.head: SUDAN GOVERNMENT RAILWAYS.
div.p: CAIRO-KHARTOUM SUMMER MAIL SERVICE.--SUMMER TIME-TABLE 1906.
Commencing from 1st of April, 1906, until further notice

‡Sleeping and Dining Cars. — During the month of April Sleeping and Dining Care trains leave Cairo for Luxor on Wednesdays, Mondays and Saturdays at 6.30 p.m. and Luxor for Cairo on Sundays, Tuesdays and Thursdays at 6.30 p.m.

From 1st of May 1908, these trains will be suppressed, but Dining and Sleeping Care will be attached to the ordinary night Tains from Cairo and Luxor three times a week, on the same above mentioned days. 14-6-907

div.head: Egyptian State Railways.
div.p: †Dining Car. §Sleeping Car. ‡First and Second Class only.
* Dining and Sleeping Cars are attached to these trains on the following days: -- From Cairo, every Monday, Wednesday and Saturday. From Luxor, every Tuesday, Thursday and Sunday.
A dining car will attached to the 11.30 a.m. Luxor to Shallal; and to the 9.10 a.m. Shallal to Luxor.
G. B. MACAULEY, General Manager.

div.head: Calvert's Carbolic Toilet Soap
div.p: Ensures a Clear, Soft Skin.

It is pure throughout, fragrantly perfumed, emollient, and antisceptic, (10% crystal carbolic). It quickly removes dust and dirt, takes away the unpleasant effects of perspiration, and leaves instead a delicious feeling of thorough purification.

div.head: EASTERN EXCHANGE HOTEL, PORT SAID.
div.p: First Class Hotel. Modern in all respects.
Fire-proof, Drained to the Sea, Lifts, Electric Light, English and French Billiards, Fresh and Salt Water Baths.
The Coolest Summer Residence in Egypt.
Special terms to Cairo Residents and their families desirous of enjoying the cool air and sea bathing during the summer months.
Dragomans in Hotel Uniform Meet all Trains and Steamers.

div.head: TEWFIK PALACE HOTEL.
div.p: HELOUAN, near CAIRO

Formerly the favourite Residence of H.H. the late Khedive. Perfect Sanitation.-Purest Desert air. Electric Light. Hot and cold baths attatched to most rooms. House warmed by special system of radiators, adjoining the Golf Links and Race Course, Tennis, Billiards, Garden and open air palm house, good stabling, dark room. Excellent Table. Moderate charges. Medical Resident Director: ARTHUR J. M. BENTLEY, M.D.-Town Office at tephenson and Co., Opera Square, Cairo.
P.E. HERGEL, Manager.

div.head: SAVOY HOTEL
div.p: LUXOR (Upper Hotel.)

Unrivalled situation. Splendid view over the Nile River. Entirely renovated. Moderate charges. Omnibus and Porter meet all trains and steamers. Special terms for Government Officials, and Officers of Army of Occupation.
Telegraphic Address:"SAVOY, LUXOR."
C and M. RUNKEWITZ, Proprietors. Also Proprietors Bean Rivage Hotel, Ramieh, Alexandria.
G. AQUILINA, Proprieter.

div.head: REMARKS.
div.p: Fine bracing weather has prevailed and still prevails, though a falling barometer betokens a coming change.

div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.
div.p: SUBSCRIPTIONS.—Alexandria, Cairo, and the Interior of Egypt (including delivery in Alexandria or postage to subscriber’s address) P.T. 231½ per annum, P.T. 116 for six months, P.T. 80 for three months. To other countries in the Postal Union P.T. 273 (£2.16s.) per annum. Six months P.T. 136½ (£1.8s.), three months P.T. 92 (£0.19s.) N.B.—Subscriptions commence from the 1st or 16th of any month.

ADVERTISEMENTS.—P.T. 4 per line. Minimum charge P.T. 20. Births, Marriages, or Deaths, not exceeding three lines, P.T. 20. Every additional line P.T. 10. Notices in news column P.T. 20 per line. Contracts entered into for standing advertisements.
ADVERTISEMENTS and SUBSCRIPTIONS are due in advance. P.O. Orders and Cheques to be made payable to the Editor and Manager, Rowland Snelling, Alexandria.
London Offices : 36, New Broad-street. B.C.
THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE can be obtained in London at our office, 36, New Broad Street, E.C.
Cairo Offices.-No. 1 Sharia Vervudachi, (opposite the Agricultural Bank.)
The Egyptian Gazette
An English Daily Newspaper, Established in 1880.
Editor & Manager: R. Snelling.
Price: One Piastre Tariff.
MONDAY, DECEMBER 10,1907.
TRAFTIC IN HONOURS

It is worth noting at a moment when there is some talk about the necessity of only granting decorations and grades in Egypt for merit, that King Edward is starting a similar movement in England. "The information which we have had placed at our disposal,” says ‘The Throne” of the24thalto.,"enables us to state with authority that His Majesty views with extreme disfavour the flagrant manner in which titles have been exploited for party purposes in recent years, and will discountenance most strongly any promotions in the future which are based upon mere liberal contributions to the party funds Titles which ought to be conferred only upon men of high distinction in the realm of intellectual activity have been knocked down to the highest bidder, and these facts have not been disclosed when the name of the prospective peer has been placed before His Majesty for approval. Sir William Jones, in his famous ode in imitation of Alcseus, has given us a magnificent ideal of the State. He reminded us, in words of singular force and beauty, that it does not consist of 'starr'd and spangled courts, where low-bred baseness wafts perfume to pride,’ but of high-minded men, 'men who their duties know, but know their rights, snd, knowing, dare maintain.’ If England as a nation is to realise that ideal, the honours which she has to confer upon her distinguished sons must not be bought and sold in the political market-place, but should be preserved as a priceless reward for those whose lofty character and intellectual equipment fit them to become the forerunners of a race of statesmen.”
P. AND O. REPORT

This great company manages to pay 13 per cent. on its Deferred stock with wonderful regularity, and it is fortunate not only in having different sources of revenue, to that where one may fail another makes good the deficiency, but also in having a thoroughly business-like board of directors. It will come as no surprise to stockholders that the freight returns for the year ended September 30 do not compare favourably with those of the previous year, though the apparent deficiency is only £67,475 on a total receipt of £1,521,309, and of this £31,600 is set down to less Government work and lower rates, but the deficiency would have been greater had it not been for the earnings of certain extra voyages. Outward Indian trade was demoralised by a conflict between the English and German lines engaged in the Antwerp branch of this trade, while homeward freights from Indian ports were considerably below the normal point, and cargo was often exceptionally scarce. In Australia freights also suffered in consequence of a fall of nearly 50 per cent in the carrying rates for refrigerated produce, and the cargo fleet engaged in the local trade between India, China, and Japan was not so fully employed as in the previous year. The passenger season, however, was a good one, the total traffic of £1,087,407 being an improvement of £102,719 on last year, but the expense of working the new vessels engaged in this service, which are much larger than the ships replaced, and the further disbursements arising from the extra voyages, materially swelled the expenditure, which, apart from the sinking fund, shows an excess in the cost of navigating the fleet of upwards of £100,000, a considerable proportion of which is attributable to the acceleration of the mail service. The net result of the year's operations is really, very satisfactory, for after setting aside for depreciation £461,097 to sinking fund,the board is enabled to recommend une dividend and bonus as last year.

div.head: MILITARY TAILORS.
div.p: EGYPTIAN ARMY OUTFITS A SPECIALITY
RIDING BREECHES.
F. PHILLIPS AND CO.
LADIES' TAILORS.
(HIGH CLASS WORK ONLY)
CAIRO AND ALEXANDRIA.
International Judicial Commission.
The International Judicial Commission will meet after the 'Xmas holidays at the Ministry of the Interior, under the presidency of Boutros Pasha Ghali Minister for Foreign Affairs.
Cairo Scientific Society.

A meeting of the society will take place at the School of Medicine on Thursday, 13th inst., at 4 30 p.m. The following papers will be read: "River Characteristics as illustrated by the Nile," by Dr. Home; "Fluctuations in the height of the subsoil water in relation to the "Nile Flood," by Mr. A. Lucas.
“The Globe Trotter"

Mr. David Garrick Longworth’s organ “The Globe Trotter" has appeared in a considerably enlarged form. From the general appearance of the paper and the large number of advertisements which it contains the "Globe Trotter" is progressing fast, and Mr. Longworth’s many friends in Egypt will be pleased to hear of his success.
"The Sphinx."

Our bright little winter contemporary, the "Sphinx," has made its debut for the season, while entering on its fourteenth year. Last week’s issue (the second this season) is if anything an improvement on the first, and both are full of interest to the resident and tourist alike. The journal has the same features as last year—society gossip in Cairo and London, chit-chat interesting personalis, visitors’ lists, "Fashions of the Moment,’’ "Finance and Matters Financial,” a short story by a well-known author, humorous tit-bits, and well-selected articles, besides a number of illustrations, etc. The addition of a new printing department equipped with the most modern machinery and the latest type has enabled the publishers to bring out a handsome publication, which does credit to all concerned.
British Club.

The smoking concert given at the British Club on Saturday was a great success in every way, and it is to be hoped will prove to be only the first of a series of similar entertainments. Mr. Heaton opened with a pianoforte solo, and ably served as so accompanist throughout. Mr. Parvis was in good form in the two solos he gave, especially in the favorite "Veteran’s Song.” He also joined Mr. Sarjeant in a fine rendering of a very telling duet, "Watchman, what of the Night!" composed by Mr. Sarjeant's brother. Mr. De Rougemont delighted every one with his whistling, which beautifully true, and also sang a couple of songs. Mr. Pearce Hill, always a favourite, brought his dolls and managed to check their hilarity though not that of the audience. Mr. Dodwell is a master hand at entertaining, and kept all in roars of laughter throughout his sketches and songs. M.D'Ambra gave four selections on the violin with charming effect and exquisite touch. The chair was taken at first by Sir Massie Blomfield, but owing to the serious illness of Lady Blomfield he had to leave at the interval, and Mr. Gould presided for the rest of the evening. Votes of thanks were pasted to the chairman, and to Mr. Sarjeant for arranging the concert. At the close the prizes won in the billiard handicap were presented by Mr. Gould to the winners, Messrs. Legge, Wood and Sampson.
Spartall & Co 's Carpets.

We would call the attention of our readers to an advertisement appearing in to-day's issue of Messrs. J. A. Spartali & Co.’s Oriental carpets. This well known firm, whose head office is at Smyrna, are the largest dealers of hand made Turkish and Persian carpets In the world, and have bean established since 1842. They are manufacturers of all their own goods, having workshops and agencies in all carpet-producing localities of Asia Minor and Persia and employing no less than 10.000 looms and 40,000 weavers; consequently, there being no intermediate profits, the firm is able to offer its goods at prices 25 % to 50 % lower than at the retail shops in Cairo and Alexandria and varying from 13 francs to 150 francs the square metre. Besides a grand selection of modern Oriental carpets of any size and colour Messrs. Sparta'i are prepared to show a choice collection of fine antique rugs and silk rugs of the very finest quality and at moderate prices. They are likewise prepared to execute orders for clients for carpets of any size and colour desired. We would mention that their goods are most suitable for Christmas and New Year's presents to relatives and friends in Europe and America. The firm warm’y invite residents and travelllers to favour their branches in Egypt with a call to inspect the stock just arrived from Smyrns and new being exhibited, with the assurance that visitors will not be importuned to purchase goods they may not require.

Captain Hollefen, oommandant of the Ger-man training ship Storch, who was granted audience by the Khedive at Abdeen Palace on Friday, returned to Alexandria on Saturday, from Cairo. The Stosch sails on Saturday next.

The Rev P. B. N. Neman-Lee, C P., is expected to arrive by the troopship Braemar Castle on Thursday next, and will forthwith resume his duties as Chaplain to the Forces in Alexandria, which since his departure in July last have been undertaken by tbe clergy of 8t. Mark’s Church. Canon Ward ceased to be Acting Chaplain to the Forces on December 1.
On their visit to Egypt this month the Earl and Countess of Halsbury will be accompanied by Mr. and Lady Evelyn Giffard.

div.head: SERIOUS TRAIN COLLISION.
div.p: TWENTY-ONE PASSENGERS INJURED.

The following telegram was received by us on Saturday evening The Railway Administration regrets to report a serious collision which occurred at Mit Assas this morning and in which one Syrian gentleman received serious injuries and three Europeans and two ladies were slightly injured. All were able to continue their journeys,with the exception of the Syrian gentleman, who was taken to hospital. Fifteen Egyptians received slight injuries, but were able to continue their journeys. The collision occurred during a thick fog. An official erquiry is being made as to the exact cause. Traffic was entirely blocked for some hours, but by this afternoon normal working was again restored. Mit Assas is on the Tautsh to Mansourah line.

div.head: BURGLARY IN CAIRO
div.p: MR. GRAHAM’S HOUSE ENTERED.

At 4 o’clock yesterday morning the house of Mr. Graham, Deputy Director General of the Public Health Department, at Ghezireh, was broken into by burglars and a considerable amount of old silver plate removed. The police have the affair in hand and are making in-vestigations which it is hoped, will lead to the discovery of the criminals.

Burglary on an extensive scale has hitherto been of rare occurrence in Egypt, but now that the large increase of the suburbs at Cairo and Alexandria offers considerable opportunities to individual or to gangs of thieves it behoves householders to be on their guard.

div.head: AT HOME" ON THE NILE.
div.p: The Hamburg and Anglo-American Nile Company gave a very pleasant "At Home” on board their dahabeah Nubia yesterday afternoon. This fine boat was moored to the land-ing-stage close to Kaar-el-Nil, and was in gala attire, palms and flowers being in profusion and every comfort provided for the guests. Asump-tuous tea was provided in the dainty saloon, which was set out with little tables, while less innocent drinks were served from the smoking-room on the upper desk. The Nubia is one of the finest of this company’s steamers, and her accommodation offers every comfort. The roomy cabins have large and airy windows ; and every window is fitted with mosquito blinds, and the cabins all contain ample shelves and chests of drawers and Other conveniences not often met with on board any boat. The upper deck is glazed in at the bows so that no untoward breeze may interfere with the comfort of the passengers ; and everything has been done to ensure the arrangements being as perfect as possible. A continuous stream of people took advantage of the company’s invitation to inspect the vessel; and though some of the guests came expecting an afternoon cruise on the river there were few who were not satisfied with the entertainment offered them.

div.head: Y. W. C. A.
div.p: The accommodation at Connaught House proving too limited, the annual sale of work given by the Y. W. C. A. will be held, with the kind permission of George Nuogovich Bey and Mr. Braun, at the Hotel Continental on December 18. The Countess of Cromer has kindly consented to open the proceedings at 3.30, being supported by the Very Rev. Dean Butcher, D.D., in the Chair, and the vote of thanks being proposed by/Major-General Bollock, C.B. By kind permission of Colonel E. A. Herbert, M.V.O., the band of the 6th Inniskilling Dragoons will play daring the afternoon. The sale of work will continue throughout the same evening, the Hon. L. M. lddings American Consul General presiding over the opening ceremony at 8.30 The music during the evening will ba provided by vocalists and a Toy Symphony, four violins and a cello being requisitioned in addition to the usual instruments. The following is a list of the patronesses and of the stalls over which they will preside : England (Children’s garments).—Mmes. Alban, Bullock, Butcher, Boyd-Carpenter, Cook-sor, Hogg. Royle, and Vera Alston. Scotland (Woollen goods)—Lady Rogers, Lady Blanche Smith, Lady Willcocks, Mmes Graham, Milton, and Mackenzie. Ireland (Linen goods). — Mmes Johnson Pasha, P. H. Rowlett. and Trevithick. America (Cakes and sweets).—Mmes Id-dings, Crookshank, Foot, Stout, and Tuck. Continent.—Lady Victoria Machell, Miss Farnell. Any contributions of needlework, cakes, sweets, flowers, etc, will be very gratefully received at Connaught House ; and we trust that our readers will take this opportunity of showing their sympathy and appreciation of this most deserving association.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS
div.p: The S.S Sailor Prince, with passengers and general cargo, left Malta on the 8th inst., and is due to arrive at Alexandria on the I2th. The Ellerman liner City of Khios arrived in Liverpool on Saturday morning. The S.S. Bulgarian (Wesscott Line) left Malta on the 8th inst., and is due here on Wednesday next with general cargo from London and Malta.

div.head: SUEZ CANAL BLOCKED.
div.p: CLAN LINER ASHORE.
(From our CORRESPONDENT.)

Suez Monday. The S.S Clan Macdonald is ashore in the Canal at kil. 146 station, and is blocking the passage of the Indian mailboat Mooltan, which has already been delayed 15 hours. Suez Later. The Clan Macdonald has been refloated, but cannot move owing to a chain in her propeller.

div.head: THE S.S. NEGHILLEH.
div.p: RETURNS TO SUEZ UNDAMAGED.

Suez, Saturday. The S.S. Calioubieh returned to Suez this forenoon. from Gemsab, and reports having successfully pulled the S.S. Neghilleb off the reefs. The vessel is apparently undamaged, and will very likely return to Suez tomorrow. Suez, Sunday. The Khedivial steamer Neghilleb, which was ashore at Gemsah, returned to Suez at 7.80 this morning and has been drydocked.

div.head: REAL ESTATE AT ALEXANDRIA.
div.p: A Cairo correspondent writer Five months ago La Societe d’Entreprises Immobilieres et de Travanx,. Cairo, made arrangements to take over 10% (80,000 pips) of the land owned by La Societe Civile des Terrains Cleopatre of Alexandria. This land has a superficial area of about .300.000 pies, and is situated at Ibrahimieh (Alexandria) on the sea front. They bought the land in Jane last from Messrs. Stagni and Zervudachi for P.T. 101 per pic. The Municipality has now decided to extend the Alexandria promenade quay as far as Sidi Gaber, which work will necessitate catting through the whole length of the Cleopatre possessions. The necessary funds for carrying out this work have already been voted by the Municipality. One can see at a glance that the value of this property has already been considerably enhanced, and it is estimated that there will be no difficulty in obtaining P.T. 200 to P.T. 230 per pic for this land. At the present moment there are firm offers on hand lor certain parcels at P.T. l60 per pic. which represents a net profit of P.T. 69 per pic on purchase price. If tbe Societe d'Entreprises Immobilidres et de Travanx ware to realize to day their portion of the property, the sale would net them a clear £18 000, and this on an expendi-ture of £7,500 made last June. As no doubt the property will be disposed of at a more advantageous figure, a considerably larger profit will result therefrom.

div.head: ZIZINIA THEATRE.
div.p: "FRANCILLON.”

"Autres temps, autres mceurs"; old de Riverolles tale of the Middle Ages seems now hardly more antiquated than Dumas 20 year-old play itself. By so much have we progressed or—become blaze. And, paradoxically, "plus ca change plus c’est la meme chose; there is the usual triangle, this time an isosceles one, its sides composed of suspicions of husband and wife married "a outrance” on a very weak basis of infidelity, and the denonement no less laborious than the Pons Asinorum. We hardly care to think how a Dumas of to-day would fare with a piece whose meagre plot and interminable dialogues are equalled only by its want of plausibility and action. The constant repetition of the main theme by nearly every character soon becomes tedious. There is hero and there a redeeming epigram, but on the whole the play offers little opportunity, nor did we think that, when produced on Saturday, that little was pushed to its uttermost possibility. Even Mile Marthe Brandes in the title idle did not mark her debut in Alexandria with anything beyond an averagely good performance. For this, no doubt a severe cold, from which she was suffering, was in a measure responsible. And then the part is wordy and refitted and hence deprives its interpreter of a good deal of the effect to be gained by appeals to the imagination. It may well be that a stage idea of the 'femme du monde' is to keep the emotions genteelly in check; still there was surely room for rather more colour and "abandon’’ in "Francillon" than Mile Brandis imparted. Setting aside M Arnaud, the present troupe is certainly better than Mme Hading’s com-pany, in that they shew confidence and pull well together. On Saturday no one player stood out from amongst the others, so it would be invidious to draw distinctions. This evening, "L'Espionne” will be give

div.head: MAPLE &Co., Ltd.
div.p: LONDON & PARIS UPHOLSTERERS TO H.M. KING EDWARD VII>

Beg to announce that their representative, Mr. T. OLIVER, is now staying at the New Khedivial Hotel. Alexandria, where he will remain till December 24th, and where he. will be pleased to make appointment at Shepheard’s Hotel, from December 25th, till the of January.

div.head: KISWET EL MAHMAL.
div.p: CEREMONY AT THE CITADEL

Topped by the mosque and ifs minarets, the Citadel stands clear against the sky: the blood , red standard scarce flatters in the morning breeze, and the ramparts are fringed will an evergrowing line of figures, clad in every abade of ooloar but mostly capped with crimson tarboosh. The crowd in the place below grows denser every moment as the morning mists roll away and carriage after carriage flits its way into the enclosure. For civilized and Europeanized as is our Cairo, this great festival, centred round the departure of the Holy Carpet for Mecca, is still one of the great events of the calendar and is eagerly awaited by both Mohamedan and Christian. The night before its departure the heavily embroidered panels and the sacred Mahmal were 'en evidence'. under cover, and great was the crowd that circled round it and joined the audience in the adjoining tent where Dervishes chanted their endless verses, and devotees persisted in their devotions till the onlookers grew weary of the drowsy monotony and strange barbaric musical intervals. But the morning ceremony held under the blue canopy of heaven and with accompaniment of military display appeals more to the ordinary observer and bolds attention from first to last. The native crowd, so full of colour and movement, the mounted police reducing chaos into semblance ,of order, the stretch of sand-covered road winding round the Citadel and up the slope beyond, the wide parade ground lined with rigid troops, and the constant stream of carriages and people, keep eyes and senses always on the alert. High officials, gorgeous in their gold-laced uniforms, with brightly coloured orders and glittering decorations, whirl by; and also many native notabilities in wonderful eastern garb and flowing garments of various hues with embroideries of gold about their necks and encircling their turbans. Some drive in state behind proudly stepping horses; others arrive in humble arabeshs, the effect made grotesque at times by the figure of a ragged urchin taking a free ride behind. Closed broughams flash by containing visions of veiled ladies of state, and the latest arrivals from England in the latest thing in motor cars presses largely to the fore. But all are ready in their places, and all the soldiers spick and span and well to attention before the clatter of the Lancer escort proclaims the arrival of H.H. the Khedive and his entourage in the highly swung barouche with syces and outriders. The strains of the National Anthem, Royal salutes, and shouts from the male population greet his arrival, while the curious twittering cries from the native women add an element most curious and unusual to the sound. In the meanwhile the Kiewet el-Mahmal has been borne into the centre of the ground : the ' gorgeous tent-like creation has been already lifted into position upon the honoured camel, all richly caparisoned and almost covered with its saddle cloth and headpiece of gold and crimson. The Mahmal itself is so overladen with heavy gold and silver bullion that scarce any of its crimson ground is visible. High silver ornaments are at its angles, its silver apex gleams from under a falling fringe of black. Swaying to the movement of the camel it scintillates and blazons in the sunshine and moves slowly across the ground past the Khedive, and starts the first stage of its long and weary journey followed by the plaintive music of flats and native drum. Stretched on long domed frames of wood, and looking for all the world like enormous ambulance litters, follow the various portions of the sacred carpet. They are carried on the stalwart shoulders of duffel clad gaffirs; and while some are covered, all with black, others display their glittering , inscriptions from the Koran upon a ground of black or green. After them stream the various regiments : first the Lancers with their band playing, somewhat inappropriately,very English music, then the guns of the field battery and the mule battery, and after them detachments of the Egyptian line. After the long stream has passed away out of sight and the final salute is over, the Khe-dive drives off in his state carriage across the ground, and the great function is over. Within half an hour the crowd has drifted back to its highways and byeways, and the Citadel is once more left to keep solitary watch and ward over the town at its feet.
NILE TOURISTS.

List of passengers by the P. S. Prince Abbas, which left Shellal yesterday: — Miss C.A. O’ding, Miss C.M. Sallivar, Mils Mannering, Miss A. and Miss D. Dr. and Mrs. MeClymont, Mr. H.8. Collins. Mrs. D. Edgar Jones, Mr. Dawson. Passenger list of S.S. Puritan which left Kasrel-Nil on Friday : — Dr. K Coutts, Jasref Bey Sahih, Mr. and Mrs. G. W. div.head: Notice for Tourists.
div.p: MOERIS HOTEL AND GRAND HOTEL KAROUN (on the Lake) Fayoum Comfortable Hotels Patronised by Princess of Batten-berg, Prince of Sweden, etc. For particulars apply A. TASCO, Proprietor.
ALEXANDRIA FIRE BRIGADE.
SATURDAY’S DISPLAY.

As a demonstration of technical ingenuity, combined with simplicity of manoeuvre, the display of the Alexandria Fire Brigade, held on Saturday afternoon, at Moharem Bey, under the direction of Miralai Hockinson, deserved the highest praise. But more than this. The feature that stood forth most conspicuously, at that exhibition,was neither the excellency of the equipment, nor the superior make of the machinery ; it was rather, if the writer’s allegory may be permitted, (he high standard of efficiency of the "human machine”— effi cient in every detail of the manifold duties involved in the fireman’s risky work. The raw, untutored, undisciplined Arab or Fellah has been taken in hand, and by the devotion of British and European instructors, formed into a handy, able-bodied man. The. engine may be perfect, hot it is after all the man behind it that tells. The brigade whom Superintendent Waller marshalled on Saturday before his Excellency the Governor and a goodly gathering of local portabilities—official and civilian- were as fine a body of men as one could wish to see ; splendid physique, and for all their swarthy faces, very imposing in their dazzling brass helme’s. There were a promptitude to obey and enthusiasm in action which augur well, and it was also not a little gratifying to note the keen delight shown by the native population, a huge concourse of whom covered the steep slope of Kom el Dik; they were especially jubilant over the operations for rescuing one of their own kith and kin,who his bare and puny legs swinging in the wind, was let down from the top storey window. The display commenced with inspection parade of brigade and equipment, consisting of three fire engines, one automobile; a manual engine ; pompier ladder; long ladder; and hose reel. To avoid tediousness, we will con-fine ourselves to a generalisation of the several , items of the programme. The drilling was , perfect, and the record of time in which the work was carried out, remarkable. For instance the manual engine was got in'o action, pump pipe, and all, by one man within 1.41 minutes. The pompier ladder, whose uses were next demonstrated, is, we believe, a French invention ; the books at the end of the short ladders employed in climbing from storey to storey reminded one of the fore feet of that interesting invertebrate, the Walking Stick insect Reaching the top of one ladder, the fireman secured himself by a catch to the sill, while he fixed on the ladder he carried to the upper floor; the rungs were attached to a centre—piece like fish- bones to the spine, and the saw—like appearance made one shudder. The rope used in the escape is of coreless multiple strand called "Simonis,” of London make, very light and thin, but of immense strength. We had also a practical demonstration of the water curtain, which so ingeniously protects the fireman by a circular spray at right angles to the jet The chemical cylinder, containing carbonic acid gas, that rapidly extinguished a fierce fire, and the smoke helmet, were also interesting. The long ladder is eighty feet in length. At full span, it looks top heavy, but except for an initial list, the carriage on which it stands scarcely creaked, no matter what way the ladder was turned. It is of German manu- factors, built by Honig of Cologne, and not the latest thing in ladders, for by the newest invention the fireman is winched up by a motor engine. But for Alexandria, which at present is free of sky scraping architecture, the German apparatus will suffice. The motor fire engine was, as with the others, constructed by the well known firm of Merryweather of London ; it was oonverted to automobility recently by an expert sent from London, Under 120 pounds pressure, or 12 H P., it can run 16| miles an bour. A word for the horses of the other engines. They are nearly all South of England breed ; they are thoroughly trained and powerful drays, which, for all the sandy roil, drew op instantaneously, even at full gallop. The "house on fire” scene was the grande finale, most realistic with just a suspicion of smoke —the spectators would have bean delighted with a good old blaze but proximity to the station buildings forbade ; or perhaps the house was too wet After the gallop past the parade reformed, and his Excellency the Governor congratulated Superintendent Waller and his men on their admirable performance.

div.head: UNITED-EGYPTIAN LANDS. LTD.
div.p: The public appear to be undersome misapprehension as to the length of time daring which their money will be locked up after having sent in their applications for shares for the United Egyptian Lands, Limited. The allotment will take place in Egypt so far as one third of the capital is concerned. The allotment letters and cheques will be sent out to applicants certainly not later than the end of the present week. The United Egyptian Lands, Limited, has secured an option, in addition to the 55,000 metres referred to in the prospectus, on land on Rodah Island. This brings up the total to over 220 000 square metres and works out at under £2.l0s. per metre, including all charges. The land is excellently situated with a frontage on the Nile. The Garden City plots are fetching from £5 to £14 per metre and the land immediately opposite at Gbizeh from £4 to £6, so the option obtained by the United lands must be considered exceptionally favourable.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL OPERA HOUSE
div.p: “FAUST
(FROM OUR THEATRICAL CORRESPONDENT.)

"Feast" opened well enough. We had three new people. M Massas Mephistopheles, Mile Baron as Margoerite, and M. M<hy as Valentine. If the whole performance had not tailed off so wretchedly we should have appreciated them. Mile Baron can act; and it is the greatest possible relief to see a Marguerite who has any notion of acting. The "Thole” song was perhaps her best achievement. The tremolo—wh'ch she uses far too much—came in as a "roucoulement”—a real spinning-wheel song. crooned to herself. The Jewel song would hare been even better, but she spoilt it by a "show” high note at the end which dramatised her soliloqoy out of its proper form Her acting was especially good in the church scene with Mephistopheles: many slight touches, her concentration on the mass-book from which her thoughts were so far absent, her painful progress across the stage kneeling— these and much else proved her merit but her voice seems tired, and now and again she uses that tremolo to avoid an awkward semitone or accidental. M. Maas was not bad, but seemed to have bad quite enongh of the play long before the end. M. Mezy has little enough to do, but his voice is good, with plenty of strength and far more 'colour' than those of the others. M. Fontaine, I was told, had been suffering from dengue. He must have had it from the beginning of the season than ; he showed the same tendency to force his notes, especially in the lower register, as he did in ‘Manon' and "Romeo and Juliette.” It is a pity, as his higher, more emotional notes are the "real thing." But why does he make up so badly! He always appears grotesque with that absurd beard and moustache arrangement In "Manon," after the first two acts he was well made up, and naturally; and it made all the difference in the world. Siebel (Mile Karl) and Marthe (Mile Burizy) were fair. The chorus end orchestra were very bad : the former were stiff, and at best noisy, and in the soldiers' chorus they looked like a lot of gaffiers on parade. The latter, as I have already said, seems to be always asleep and flat. The conductor has no sort of entrain. He gets through it all anyhow and never makes a point of any sort. No wonder the operas go badly! The famous Escalais appears at length in 'William Tell tomorrow (Saturday) night; so we shall see the company in its more serious aspect. Let us hope for a vivid and striking contrast to the first few efforts. It is, I think, no use people talking (as I have heard and read lately) about the small Opera House, the difficulties, etc, etc. I can't see any sort of excuse for the shortcomings. We need not expect Caruso and Melba, but surely the receipts end whatever help the company get should ensure at least a really good second-class troupe. Really, when one is driven to indulgence in comparison with the Abbas and ci-devantt Verdi Theatres, with any stage where any singing can be heard, one resents hearing the Opera Home spoken of as the chief Khedivial Theatre, etc.. etc. No one likes having dost thrown in his eyes!

div.head: ‘GUILLAUME TELL'
div.p: ''Guillaume Tell” was a startling and wel-come change. M Escalais, Mezy. Mass, and Mile Devilloy are all four, of a different class to any we have yet heard : they are grand opera, and very good grand opera at that. M. Escalais has a great resonant voice : his high notes are those of a clarion shaking and echoing through the house; his diction and declamation are those of a great singer. Of course his acting and, in a sense, some of his singing are entirely stereotyped and traditional: be is, except for those high notes, a type and not an individual He sang rather flat now and again in the lower and middle registers and was inclined to skirt round the note ; and in those same registers was a suspicion of wear and tear and effort His finest singing was in the duet with Mathilde. the "J'expire" and the trio, and the two songs in the last act, “Mes ami." and ‘’Asile muet” M. Mass was more at home than as Mephistopheres, and the depth and "roundness" of his voice had foull scope. M. Mezy though, was the triumph of the evening. His voice, a great baritone, had every shade of strength and colour and drama : and his acting was equally fine and not nearly so strewed as that of the rest. Mile Deviloy had not half enough to do, from our point of view. She is, I really think, the most perfect of the sopranos. She has far more tone than Mile Baron, and though she has hardly the training of Mile Charpentier, her voice is infinitely sweeter: never a disagreeable or harsh note, or a shadow of fatigue or thinness, and her notes were sweetness itself. Those phases of the opera I have mentioned, -and I add Mezy's singing and acting before "Gessler”—were as near perfection as could be. As for the rest, the orchestra did the overtore well, and kept to a fairly good standard most of the time ; but in the trio— Walther, Arnold and Guillaume Tell—it was again shaky and inaccurate. The players do not respond enough. Mile Karl acted well all through, but her singing lacks certainty : she never seems sure of herself or her voice. M. Durand looked like Henry VIII. in a most tyrannical "get-up," and sang well enough. The others one may as well pass over. The chorus must have a special condemnation. The breakdown in the 3rd act, the general tuneless-ness and carelessness seem to show an entire lack of drilling or training. I admit most of them seemed to know it, and to be sorry for what was probably not their fault; but one or two of the worst offenders (I think they were in last year’s chorus) seemed hopelessly satisfied with themselves and stared and sang into vacancy with the most deplorable aplomb. Of ballets, I am no judge : opinions seemed to differ; but certainly I am thankful in that the vision of fleshly poetry of motion caused one worthy at least behind me to stop making horrible noises with programme, feet, throat, and other accessories that were not meant by the Creator as annoyances to one's fellow-creatures! At one moment I would have given much for a powerful and wide-spreading narcotic for use in the stalls.
